qas.question: What did most early home computers develop?
What did Kaypro CP/M computers use?

answers.text: the "upper" 128 characters for the Greek alphabet

qas.question: What did IBM PC replace the control-characters with?

answers.text: graphic symbols such as smiley faces

qas.question: What did Digital Equipment Corporation develop?
What did Macintosh use instead of graphics?
What did most early graphic characters develop?

plausible_answers.text: graphic symbols such as smiley faces

qas.question: What did IBM PC replace the code pages with?
What did Macintosh use instead of hardware?
What did Digital Equipment Corporation develop for use in game glyphs?
What replaced the Greek alphabet with graphic symbols?

context: Most early home computer systems developed <a0_0><b5_0>their own 8-bit character sets<b5_0/><a0_0/> containing line-drawing and game glyphs, and often filled in some or all of the control characters from 0–31 with more graphics. Kaypro CP/M computers used <a1_0>the "upper" 128 characters for the Greek alphabet<a1_0/>. The IBM PC defined <b9_0>code page 437<b9_0/>, which replaced the control-characters with <a2_0><b6_0>graphic symbols such as smiley faces<b6_0/><a2_0/>, and mapped additional graphic characters to the upper 128 positions. Operating systems such as DOS supported these code pages, and manufacturers of IBM PCs supported them in hardware. Digital Equipment Corporation developed <b8_0>the <a3_0>Multinational Character Set (DEC-MCS)<b8_0/><a3_0/> for use in the popular VT220 terminal as one of the first extensions designed more for international languages than for block graphics. The Macintosh defined Mac OS Roman and Postscript also defined a set, both of these contained both international letters and <a4_0><b7_0>typographic punctuation marks<b7_0/><a4_0/> instead of graphics, more like modern character sets.
